commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

commentText:
Spectrum Health Lakeland respectfully submits these comments in response to the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) Advanced Notice of Proposed Rule Making published in the Federal Register on October 30, 2018, regarding the International Pricing Index (IPI) Model for Medicare Part B drugs.  Spectrum Health Lakeland serves the Southwest Lower Michigan area as a Disproportionate Share Hospital under the 340B Program.  Spectrum Health Lakeland serves many low-income patients in the Southwest Lower Michigan area as evidenced by our CMS Disproportionate Share Percentage of 20.17%.  The 340B program is intended to provide resources to hospitals serving high volumes of low-income patients to enable those hospitals to provide more comprehensive services and treat more patients.

Spectrum Health Lakeland supports CMS for its efforts to reduce drug prices.  We are concerned, however, that the IPI Model would unintentionally eliminate the 340B program, which would negatively impact the ability of safety-net providers to treat low-income and vulnerable patients.  We also have several operational and patient care concerns relating to the IPI Model.  We ask that CMS consider measures to preserve the 340B program and address the patient care and operational issues in the attached file.

commentText:
APhA is pleased to submit comments to CMSs advance notice of proposed rulemaking (ANPRM) to solicit public comments on potential options for testing changes to payment for certain separately payable Part B drugs and biologicals. APhA, founded in 1852 as the American Pharmaceutical Association, represents 62,000 pharmacists, pharmaceutical scientists, student pharmacists, pharmacy technicians, and others interested in improving medication use and advancing patient care. APhA members provide care in all practice settings, including community pharmacies, hospitals, long-term care facilities, community health centers, physician offices, ambulatory clinics, managed care organizations, hospice settings, and the uniformed services. 

APhA strongly supports patient access to affordable and cost-effective medications and appreciates HHSs continued efforts to look at ways to improve efficiencies and reduce patients rising prescription drug costs by reforming current Medicare reimbursement models. As CMS notes in the ANPRM, many Part B medications are expensive, making it difficult for providers, including pharmacies, particularly those which are small, to float the inventory expense of these products for an extended period. In addition, it is administratively burdensome for pharmacists and pharmacies to obtain reimbursement for the Part B drugs they are able to provide, and reimbursements often fail to cover the actual cost of the product. As a result, patient access to many of these needed Part B medications is hindered because pharmacies cannot provide many of these products due to inadequate reimbursement and often undergo a complicated and time-consuming audit process requiring dozens of pages of documentation. APhA appreciates CMS testing any new model before implementing this policy more broadly but has some concerns with the proposed IPI model and offers the following comments. (See, attached .PDF for full comments). 

We appreciate CMSs continued work to spend health care dollars more cost-effectively for the benefit of the Medicare Program and its beneficiaries. As CMS moves forward, we hope you will use APhA as a resource. Thank you again for the opportunity to provide information on this important issue. If you have any questions or require additional information, please contact Michael Baxter, Director of Regulatory Affairs, at mbaxter@aphanet.org or by phone at (202) 429-7538.

title: TX

commentText:
CMS is still moving in a wrong headed direction in pricing prescriptions in my opinion.  The vast majority of drugs covered under Medicare Part B could and should be covered under the Medicare prescription drug program, Medicare Part D.  The current procedure causes many problems for patients and providers, primarily pharmacies.  In some cases there is a disconnect so patients may not receive needed medications since it is not completely clear as to where the drug should be billed.  Pharmacies cannot continue to guess whether Part B or Part D is the appropriate billing mechanism.  In some cases a patient could be Part D eligible and also on dialysis, plus possibly in a rehab bed in a nursing home creating a billing dilemma.  Add hospice to the list and there can be other problems also.  

CMS has also created NADAC, National Average Drug Acquisition Cost, database.  This is a very good data base that pays pharmacies appropriately.  This should be used for virtually all drug pricing, including Part D prescriptions, hospice, dialysis, rehab patients, and any other Federal Government prescription drug pricing program.  With this pharmacies need to be compensated at a level that covers their cost to dispense based on state averages.  Each state Medicaid program had to conduct a survey recently or use an average of the surrounding states.  Also the National Community Pharmacist Association and National Association of Chain Drug Stores has conducted 2 surveys in the last 10 years and correlate very well with the state values.  

Do not re-invent the wheel and spend time trying to figure out something new when a method is already available.
title: Ban Coble, KS

commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

title: TX

commentText:
This proposed legislation would require pharmaceutical companies to sell their medicines in the United States for no more than the median price charged in five countries  Canada, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, and Japan. If companies refuse to cut prices in the United States, the federal government could revoke existing patents or market exclusivities and allow generic drug manufacturers to sell knockoff copies of the medicines.

Such bills are deeply misguided. They'd stifle medical research, cutting Americans off from potentially life-saving new therapies.
Bringing a new drug to market is a monumental endeavor. It takes $2.6 billion and more than 10 years to do so, according to a study from the Tufts Center for the Study of Drug Development.

Researchers need to recoup this investment when the drug goes to market. If they can't price medications accordingly, then innovation isn't financially feasible. That would deprive patients of crucial new cures.

Plenty of research confirms this. One analysis of 25 major markets worldwide revealed that countries that had lower projected prices or smaller markets for new drugs launched fewer new drugs. It also took a longer time to launch those drugs. Another comprehensive study conducted at the University of Pennsylvania found that price controls would cause research and development intensity to decline between 36 and 48 percent.

Currently, the U.S. is a leader in medical innovation. We fund nearly half of the entire world's medical research and development, according to The Council of Economic Advisers. And from 2000 to 2010 (among the United States, France, Germany, Japan, Switzerland, and the U.K.) the U.S. companies produced 57 percent of new chemical entities, according to a report from the Milken Institute.

If the United States imposes drug price controls, medical innovation will grind to a halt, and ultimately hurt patients. This must not be allowed happen.

European-style socialist drug price controls on American companies, will bring medical development will come to a halt, cutting off our access to potentially life-saving medicines. Please do not allow these Socialist styled price controls. Thank you

commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.
title: LA

commentText: Please refrain from supporting socialized health care - it has not benefitted the citizens wherever it has been implemented and will harm the welfare of Americans. We need market based solutions with choice fo the consumer

The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

title: KS

commentText:
As a rheumatologist,  I feel this could significantly harm our infusion buy and bill practice since our average margin is significantly higher than asp + 6% for most of our Medicare part B drugs. This is due to the rebates and discounts we receive. This revenue is needed to pay for the high administrative costs of running our practice, which includes obtaining prior authorizations for buy and bill and specialty pharmacy drugs, and  initiating and maintaining patients on free drug programs. This is very important in order to keep patients compliant with our treatment pathways, which are designed to increase the value of care we deliver.  We would be forced to reduce our staff #s significantly if buy and bill revenue is limited to 6% of ASP, and even more so if ASP were reduced by 30%. As a consequence, our ability to deliver high value care would be compromised. 


The reduction of income for rheumatologists in general would likely worsen the already existing shortage of rheumatologists practicing in the United States. This is because rheumatologists are one of the lowest paid specialists. 

Given that the group I belong to has multiple practices utilizing buy and bill drugs over a widespread geographic area, if part of our practice is included in the trial period, that would be a huge disruption to our business.

title: Aaron Shore, OR

commentText:
Dear Sir/Madam,

I have been a private practice retina specialist for ten years and have witnessed in horror the high drug prices we pay in the United States versus the other countries. This includes everything from injectables to eye drops.  The high prices of the injectables in my clinic have prevented me from making it available to many patients due to the cost especially in light of uncertainty whether insurances will reimburse for these costly drugs.  Many patients, especially the poor can access these drugs more easily.  I can also afford to include these injectables for my free patients as many need them right now, if the prices are lowered. 

Yes the drug companies would argue that it will stifle innovation and lower the stock prices and what not, but why not have the Europeans, the Japanese and other wealthy nations share the cost, rather than charging Americans 5-30 times what it cost overseas.  The extent of the price differences are so dramatic, you don't see it in essentials like food, oil or car prices, and even the non-essentials.  My academic colleagues on the drug company dough will tell you that it will affect their "research dollars" but I believe our profession as physicians is to care for the well-being of the patients.  We also need to preserve the financial health of Medicare so it will be available for years to come.  I also believe the drug sales volume will increase partially offset the profit loss by the drug companies, in the process of helping more patients.  

If CME can require me, as a physician to charge Medicare patients less than my cash paying patients, I don't see why we can't do this for the drug companies.  Sure, I would like to charge 500 dollars a visit, and I believe I am worth it, but as a Medicare provider I have agreed to the CMS lower pricing. Physicians have endured cuts down to bare bones where many are leaving the profession and Medicare. I don't see anything wrong with doing that for a drug where the price of one injection surpasses my Medicare payment for all the other patients combined that day.  If that's the true price, then charge it equally across the globe.  If we are only the ones paying the inflated prices, this needs to stop.  Other large economies don't need us to subsidize.  We are already in debt up to our ears.  We need to do something both to preserve Medicare and help our patients.  Thank you for your consideration.
title: Jeffery Chung, MD

commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

commentText:
Comments regarding CMS-5528-ANPRM
Proposed Rule for Medicare International Pricing Index Model for Medicare Part B Drugs


This proposed test model adds yet another layer/middleman to the drug contracting, acquisition and delivery process already in place.  While healthcare providers are in agreement that lower drug pricing is a necessity this proposed model appears to lessen provider/physician influence over patient care and increase the complexity of an already complex system.  Very few healthcare providers are making large margins on Medicare reimbursed drug infusions.  It is preferred for CMS to negotiate directly with the pharmaceutical industry and require the industry to supply hospitals with discounted drugs for their Medicare population (somewhat like the 340b program) rather than create additional operational burdens for providers.

I fear that this proposed model will influence drug selection similar to the current Prescription Drug Benefit Managers and ultimately open sites to directly compete with healthcare providers to provide direct patient care.  I would also assume that the commercial payors will get involved to be become these private sector vendors.  This opens the door for expanding the practice of how the middlemen make their dollars through rebates and payments which will not result in the price transparency CMS is hoping to achieve. 

Requests for Feedback and Information related to Model Vendor:
The only way this proposal will work is if the relationship between the model vendors and health care providers should purely be transactional around drug purchasing and distribution.  There is mention in the proposed model about shared savings and reducing overall costs in the proposed guideline; however, the cost reduction should purely come from the changes to the drug cost via the pricing index changes.  This begs the question on why someone would want to be a model vendor (i.e. what is in it for them).  The model vendors will need to look for ways to generate revenue outside of just applying minor cost mark-ups per transaction.  This then starts looking like the Prescription Drug Benefit model which there is limited (even conflicting) data that these models produce overall value to patients and health care economics.

This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. commentText:
ANPRM: Potential International Pricing Index Model for Medicare Part B Drugs
	The International Pricing Index (IPI) Model proposed in CMS-5528-ANPRM is predicated on the assertion that the United States (U.S.) Medicare program pays higher prices for prescription medications than economically-similar countries (Executive Summary, page 4). This assertion is based on a Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) analysis of acquisition costs for 27 Medicare Part B physician-administered drugs in the U.S. compared to the cost of these drugs in 16 other developed [countries], including Austria, Belgium, Canada, Czech Republic, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Portugal, Slovakia, Spain, Sweden, and the United Kingdom (2. International Prices relative to U.S. Prices, pp. 14-15). This analysis found that U.S. prices for these 27 drugs were 1.8 times higher than the countries compared, with the U.S. listing the highest prices for 19 of the 27 products examined (2. International Prices relative to U.S. Prices, pp. 14-15).
	The conclusion drawn from these international data that Medicare beneficiaries and the Medicare Program are bearing unnecessary, potentially avoidable costs for Part B drugs should be re-examined in light of recent data from a six-year, 25 country study of price determination across international pharmaceutical markets for a comprehensive list products from the MIDAS IMS database shows that U.S. drug prices are not significantly higher in the U.S. than in other developed economies, especially those countries that are lightly regulated (Cabrales & Jimnez-Martn, 2013).
	The countries studied include Argentina, Brazil, Egypt, Italy, Austria, Belgium, France, Greece, Japan, Portugal, Spain, Australia, Canada, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Hungary, Holland, Norway, Poland, Sweden, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom, (Cabrales & Jimnez-Martn, 2013), which encompasses 10 of the economies examined in the HHS analysis. The study found that in less regulated, developed countries, there was little evidence that average prices for drugs were higher in the U.S. than in other, similar economies (Cabrales & Jimnez-Martn, 2013). In fact, evidence showed that for very common drugs, such as generic products for which there is a competitive market in the U.S., prices in the U.S. were lower than those in other developed countries where less competition in unbranded generic products exists due to universal health care systems (Cabrales & Jimnez-Martn, 2013).
	The Cabrales and Jimnez-Martn study results contradict the assertion that U.S. drug prices are higher than those in other developed countries. In other lightly regulated countries prices were shown to be higher or similar to U.S. prices, especially concerning products for which other developed nations cannot exert price controls or which are not subject to free market competition. The study also found that multinational firms in all developed countries enjoy a price advantage, and that it is only non-multinational firms in the U.S. or similar economies that offer lower prices to consumers in order to effectively compete with larger firms (Cabrales & Jimnez-Martn, 2013). 
	Thus, even in similar economies with universal health care systems drug prices are not driven primarily by regulation, consumer needs, or social welfare considerations, but by the market power of U.S. and foreign multinational corporations. Long-term incentives to innovation for and regulation of U.S. and foreign multinational corporations across developed nations may be the way to curb drug prices over time (Cabrales & Jimnez-Martn, 2013). At present, however, there is little evidence that U.S. drug prices on most products are significantly higher than those in other countries, or that price control innovation exerted only in the U.S. will make a significant difference in the prices U.S.-based multinational drug firms are able to command in this and other developed countries (Cabrales & Jimnez-Martn, 2013). Further study to ascertain socially-beneficial benchmarks for drug prices is needed and desirable (Cabrales & Jimnez-Martn, 2013), but in the meantime, attempts to bring Medicare formulary prices in line with prices for similar products in other developed economies may be based on the false premise that drug prices are higher than those in other countries, and a lack of understanding of how multinational market forces are driving drug prices higher internationally. It is therefore unlikely, in this commentators view, that CMS alone can adequately influence international drug market forces to lower drug prices for the benefit of Medicare beneficiaries and Medicare.

Reference:
Cabrales, A., & Jimnez-Martn, S. (2013). The determinants of pricing in pharmaceuticals: are US prices really so high? Health Economics., 22(11), 13771397. https://doi.org/10.1002/hec.2887
title: Johanna Lolax, MA

commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

commentText:
December 27, 2018

Via Federal eRulemaking Portal: http://www.regulations.gov

Seema Verma
Administrator
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services 
Department of Health and Human Services
P.O. Box 8013
Baltimore, MD 21244-8013

Re: 	CMS-5528-ANPRM
	Comments on CMS Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking International Pricing Index Model for Medicare Part B Drugs 

Dear Administrator Verma:

Avera Creighton Hospital appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking ("Advanced Notice") regarding the International Pricing Index (IPI) Model for Medicare Part B Drugs.  Avera Creighton Hospital is a critical access hospital (CAH) that participates in the 340B program by virtue of providing safety net services to individuals located in rural and remote locations in the United States. CAHs face significant financial challenges and often struggle to keep their doors open. In fact, 90 rural hospitals have closed since 2010.  

We applaud the Administration's efforts to address the issue of high drug prices. CMS appears to be focused on using the IPI Model to test changes in payment for drugs that are currently paid by Medicare Part B based on average sales price (ASP). CMS intends for the IPI Model to incentivize providers to seek out lower costs for drugs and reduce inappropriate utilization by changing the add-on payment for drugs paid based on ASP. However, CMS has solicited feedback on whether to include CAHs in the IPI Model. Medicare recognizes that CAHs are unique and pays CAHs based on costs, not ASP. As providers that are not paid based on ASP, CMS does not need to include CAHs in the model to achieve its goals. For this reason and given the unique patient populations that we treat, and the challenges rural patients could face in accessing care if our hospital were included in the model, we ask that CMS exclude CAHs from the model. 



In addition, we are concerned that including our hospital in the IPI Model could limit our patients access to Part B drugs or disrupt their treatment. For example, model vendors could restrict how hospitals order drugs by requiring hospitals to submit patient and/or prescription information prior to shipping the drugs, limiting which hospital locations are able to receive drug shipments, or limiting the amount of inventory hospitals are able to access in advance of patient treatment. Such disruptions to the distribution system could also increase white/brown bagging practices, which could lead to drug safety and efficacy issues for patients. This impact would be especially problematic for our patients who may need to travel significant distances to receive care. For example, Avera Health is a rural healthcare system that spans over a four state area.  We try to help local patients receive services and infusions closer to home at their rural hospitals when working with specialty physicians within the Avera Health system to improve patient care and minimize patient travel time and costs.   


Participating in the IPI Model would also create operational burdens that could affect our ability to treat patients. Model participants would need to track model drugs given to Part B patients, which would require the creation of a manual process or investment in software to track model drugs. These operational burdens would be especially challenging for 340B hospitals, which already operate complex management systems to manage 340B and non-340B drug inventories. Imposing additional inventory tracking requirements on 340B hospitals would strain our scarce resources and further limit our ability to treat rural patients. 

We appreciate the opportunity to provide comments on this Advanced Notice. For the reasons outlined above, we respectfully urge CMS to exclude CAHs from the IPI Model.

Sincerely,

Avera Creighton Hospital

title: IL

commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

title: DC

commentText:
See attached file(s)

RE: CMS-5528-ANPRM

To whom it may concern:

The Illinois Biotechnology Innovation Organization (iBIO) is writing you today to express opposition to its proposed demonstration test of attempting to align Medicare Part B drug pricing with pricing found in other countries. 

iBIO is the life sciences industry association that represents the 85,000 life sciences employees at member companies, universities, service providers and venture firms in Illinois. iBIO promotes the industrys value to the public and policymakers; connects innovators to investment and talent; stimulates collaboration and fosters the next generation of innovators and entrepreneurs to transform patient lives through groundbreaking research and works to grow the Illinois economy. 

As a state affiliate of the Biotechnology Innovation Organization (BIO), we join them in requesting withdrawal of this International Pricing Index (IPI) proposal in exchange for a broader review, discussion and consideration of alternative approaches to providing patients adequate access to needed treatments. If CMS makes the significant shift from a market-based payment formula to one based on foreign prices, we are concerned this will negatively impact research and development of new drugs desperately needed in the treatment of Medicare recipients. Please refer to BIOs submitted comments for further detail regarding our position on this issue. 

iBIOs life sciences sector supports over 85,000 jobs in the state.  Our states economic output in total value of goods and services supported by the biopharmaceutical industry sector is estimated at over $50 billion dollars based on a 2017 report prepared by TECHONOMY.  The report estimates average annual compensation at just over $119,000 in this sector in Illinois. Over $805 million in National Institutes of Health investments were made in Illinois in 2017.

We are hopeful CMS will engage in a revised discussion of proposals that focus on solutions that truly assist patients with reducing their out-of-pocket costs while maintaining and improving access to a full range of needed treatment options. Moving from a market-based pricing system to a system based on foreign pricing jeopardizes patient access, investment and research in innovative treatment solutions as well as the economic growth generated by this sector in our state.  

Please withdraw this proposal in favor of a renewed dialogue among our industry and related stakeholders to consider a more viable solution. 

Respectfully submitted,

John Conrad
President & CEO
Illinois Biotechnology Innovation Organization

commentText:
December 28, 2018

Via Federal eRulemaking Portal: http://www.regulations.gov

Seema Verma
Administrator
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services 
Department of Health and Human Services
P.O. Box 8013
Baltimore, MD 21244-8013

Re: 	Comments on CMS Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking International Pricing Index Model for Medicare Part B Drugs (CMS-5528-ANPRM)

Dear Administrator Verma:

Riverside Health System appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (CMS-5528-ANPRM) regarding the International Pricing Index (IPI) Model for Medicare Part B Drugs. Like CMS, our organization is also concerned with the high cost of pharmaceuticals, especially in comparison to other developed countries.  Riverside appreciates CMS intent to use competitive forces to lower drug prices in Medicare Part B via the IPI model, but is concerned with the number of outstanding questions and unintended consequences of the proposal. Section 1115A of the Social Security Act (Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation) calls for testing of innovative payment and service delivery models while preserving or enhancing the quality of care furnished to patients.  We have concerns that the model, as proposed, would decrease coordination, quality and efficiency of care provided.  In addition, as proposed, the model jeopardizes the integrity of the 340B drug discount program. Our health system participates in the 340B drug pricing program, which has provided safety-net hospitals relief from high drug costs since the program's enactment in 1992.  

While we applaud the Administration's commitment to addressing the issue of high drug prices, we are concerned about the potential unintended implications to patient access, the increased burden on hospital operations, and the impact to the 340B program. Our organization has already had significant impact due to the 1/1/18 reduction in reimbursement under OPPS, impacting our ability to continue to provide comprehensive health care services to our community.  

The IPI Model has many unintended consequences that must be addressed to minimize implications to hospitals, other healthcare providers and Medicare beneficiaries
 
As outlined in the Advanced Notice, the IPI model contains many outstanding questions and unintended consequences that have the potential to drastically impact the healthcare system. In order to ensure the model does not inadvertently impact patient care or impede access to care, CMS must address these issues and areas of concern prior to proceeding with a demonstration model in Medicare Part B. These outstanding questions and unintended consequences include:  
 
Mandatory Model representing 50% of Medicare Part B utilization

Calculation of ASP
 
340B Program 
 
Provider Burden 
 
Manufacturer Incentives
 
Limited Distribution Drugs 
 
Vendor Protections 

Vendor Fees 
 
Vendor Billing 

IT Infrastructure

Implementation Timeline 

Downstream Impact, including patient care implications

Exacerbation of drug shortages due to market segmentation


Riverside Health System appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on CMS-5528ANPRM. Riverside looks forward to modifications to the proposed rule-making, with a goal of upholding the intent of Section 1115A of the Social Security Act, using competitive forces to lower drug prices in the Medicare Part B program while minimizing unintended consequences to providers and patients, and maintaining the integrity of the 340B program.  
 
 
Sincerely,

 

Cynthia Williams, BS Pharm, FASHP
Vice President/Chief Pharmacy Officer
Riverside Health System
500 J Clyde Morris Blvd
Newport News, VA  23601

commentText:
This plan to decrease Medicare drug prices, would discourage innovation for pharmaceutical companies. For rheumatology practices, there would be increased and perhaps unsustainable burden.  By removing the buy and bill option it would negatively affect small business physician offices from providing infusion services.  The costs of infusions in a physicians office are substantially lower than those at an infusion center or hospital.  This plan would eliminate the ability of these small businesses to provide these services. It in some cases force them to reduce their workforce thus cutting jobs.  Further from a personal perspective, as the principle recruiter for my office, this plan would effectively destroy my ability to attract highly qualified Rheumatologists to the Midwest.  
This plan has unintended consequences that would negatively affect patients first and foremost but also small physician offices.  This would then put infusion services on hospitals which will gladly accept and actually lead to an increased cost onto the patients with facility fees and other unintended costs.  Further the higher costs are a trade off to our amazing ability to generate new and important medications.  The morbidity and mortality rates on cancers and inflammatory conditions such as Rheumatoid Arthritis have drastically changed in a positive direction just in the past 10 years alone.  This policy would immediately put a halt to that progress and unduly harm patients.  Around the world America is regarded as the researchers/innovators with unparalleled access to care. We should be prideful of this and not limit access. Socialized medicine limits access to new drugs as evidenced by the Australian and European formularies. This change is essentially doing the opposite of this administrations policy towards socialized medicine with comparing our countrys access and costs to other countries.

commentText:
RE:  CMS-5528-ANPRM
     Thank you for the opportunity to respond to the International Pricing Index Model for Medicare Part B Drugs.  I represent 35,000 retired teachers covered on a Medicare Advantage plan since 2007 and covered on a Medicare Part D EGWP inside a group purchasing alliance since 2012.  My role for 17 years now has been to contain costs without shifting costs to the retirees while keeping the Medicare coverage as valuable to the retirees as possible.  We have been staunch supporters of fair and reasonable drug prices including the use of generic and biosimilar drugs, where appropriate.  This comment is not to be construed as a stance on price controls vs. the free market as both elements already exist within Medicare plans, in that Medicare's regional fee schedules already represent price controls and Medicare Advantage or Part C of Medicare is run by private insurance companies with competition similar to that of the free market.
       Again, we are staunch supporters of fair and reasonable drug prices, and we want to be part of any potential solution instead of perpetuating unfair drug prices by continuing to pay for them.  Medicare Part B drugs are those normally administered by a physician, and the physician is reimbursed by Medicare based upon the non-negotiated Average Sales Price (ASP) + a 6% add on.  I would like to request that we be considered for participation in any future models or demonstration projects that would include testing alternative pricing models to the existing reimbursement pricing structure of ASP + 6%.  This request includes participation in any pricing models that help to fairly share the costs of necessary Research and Development (R&D) for the much needed innovator drugs that patients from all countries benefit yet only patients and health plans in the United States are charged.  My contact information is included in this response form.

The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

commentText:
Below are questions submitted from Wolters Kluwer in response to the recently issued Advance Notice of Proposed Rulemaking on the International Pricing Index (IPI) Model for Medicare Part B Drugs (CMS-5528-ANPRM). Thanks for the opportunity to submit our questions:
1.	What is the process to be used by CMS to collect international drug sales and pricing data? Will this process be similar to the one CMS already uses to calculate NADAC prices? 
2.	What safeguards will CMS employ to ensure that the data received from manufacturers on their international drug sales and pricing is accurate and timely?
3.	What is the rationale for collecting the drug pricing and sales data on a quarterly basis? Drug prices frequently fluctuate, and a drug may have undergone more than one price change within the proposed 3-month window. Would CMS consider collecting the information monthly to ensure greater accuracy?
4.	In the ANPRM, CMS requests feedback for ways to ensure confidentiality of manufacturer reporting of their international drug pricing data submitted to the agency. This implies that CMS does not intend to make such data publicly available. If this is the case, what is the rationale for this decision? 
5.	Does CMS intend to publicly release the IPI price that is calculated using the manufacturer submitted data? If so, what will be the manner, timing and frequency of such disclosure? If CMS does not intend to release the IPI price, what is the rationale for this decision? 

Thank you again for allowing us to pose these questions, and we look forward to CMS' response.

Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

The Council for Affordable Health Coverage (CAHC) is pleased to respond to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (ANPRM) regarding an International Pricing Index (IPI) model for Medicare Part B Drugs. 

CAHC is a broad-based alliance with a singular focus: bringing down the cost of health care for all Americans. commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

commentText: Attached please find the Biotechnology Innovation Organization's comments on the Advance Notice of Proposed Rulemaking for the International Pricing Index Model for Medicare Part B Drugs [CMS-5528-ANPRM].
title: DC

commentText: Reject socialized price controls on prescription drugs!
title: TX

commentText:
December 27, 2018

Via Federal eRulemaking Portal: http://www.regulations.gov

Seema Verma
Administrator
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services 
Department of Health and Human Services
P.O. Box 8013
Baltimore, MD 21244-8013

Re: 	CMS-5528-ANPRM
	Comments on CMS Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking International Pricing Index Model for Medicare Part B Drugs 

Dear Administrator Verma:

Landmann-Jungman Memorial Hospital Avera appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking ("Advanced Notice") regarding the International Pricing Index (IPI) Model for Medicare Part B Drugs.  Landmann-Jungman Memorial Hospital Avera is a critical access hospital (CAH) that participates in the 340B program by virtue of providing safety net services to individuals located in rural and remote locations in the United States. CAHs face significant financial challenges and often struggle to keep their doors open. In fact, 90 rural hospitals have closed since 2010.  

We applaud the Administration's efforts to address the issue of high drug prices. CMS appears to be focused on using the IPI Model to test changes in payment for drugs that are currently paid by Medicare Part B based on average sales price (ASP). CMS intends for the IPI Model to incentivize providers to seek out lower costs for drugs and reduce inappropriate utilization by changing the add-on payment for drugs paid based on ASP. However, CMS has solicited feedback on whether to include CAHs in the IPI Model. Medicare recognizes that CAHs are unique and pays CAHs based on costs, not ASP. As providers that are not paid based on ASP, CMS does not need to include CAHs in the model to achieve its goals. For this reason and given the unique patient populations that we treat, and the challenges rural patients could face in accessing care if our hospital were included in the model, we ask that CMS exclude CAHs from the model. 



In addition, we are concerned that including our hospital in the IPI Model could limit our patients access to Part B drugs or disrupt their treatment. For example, model vendors could restrict how hospitals order drugs by requiring hospitals to submit patient and/or prescription information prior to shipping the drugs, limiting which hospital locations are able to receive drug shipments, or limiting the amount of inventory hospitals are able to access in advance of patient treatment. Such disruptions to the distribution system could also increase white/brown bagging practices, which could lead to drug safety and efficacy issues for patients. This impact would be especially problematic for our patients who may need to travel significant distances to receive care. For example, Avera Health is a rural healthcare system that spans over a four state area.  We try to help local patients receive services and infusions closer to home at their rural hospitals when working with specialty physicians within the Avera Health system to improve patient care and minimize patient travel time and costs.   


Participating in the IPI Model would also create operational burdens that could affect our ability to treat patients. Model participants would need to track model drugs given to Part B patients, which would require the creation of a manual process or investment in software to track model drugs. These operational burdens would be especially challenging for 340B hospitals, which already operate complex management systems to manage 340B and non-340B drug inventories. Imposing additional inventory tracking requirements on 340B hospitals would strain our scarce resources and further limit our ability to treat rural patients. 

We appreciate the opportunity to provide comments on this Advanced Notice. For the reasons outlined above, we respectfully urge CMS to exclude CAHs from the IPI Model.

Sincerely,

Landmann-Jungman Memorial Hospital Avera

title: MN

commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

commentText:
Dear Sir/Madam:

The proposed rule changes may make a very tangled system easier to navigate with flat reimbursement and little or
no utilization management or formulary restrictions. However, beware of the issues of unintended consequences. The model will 
seriously impact the margin of profit severely which helps private practices maintain their operating capability. Without some 
reasonable such margin, private practice infusions of life saving and life altering medications will have to be shunted to more 
expensive locations including hospitals. Hospitals have 340B pricing structure and inherently charge and receive larger margins
which ultimately cost the system and society severely. 

Rather than proceed in this fashion, CMS would be better served to direct the flow of infusible medications to private practices 
where the physicians have more direct oversight of the medical care of the infusions and cost the system less. CMS should 
focus on the cost to the system of the PBM model in which vast amounts of monies are siphoned away from patients, care 
providers, and medical institutions to financiers whose profit deprives those most in need of the monies to direct and receive medical care.

Other points to consider include:

o The model in the ANPRM would move 50 percent of the included Part B drugs under Medicare to an untested distribution 
model, putting patient access at risk and affect the ASP  reimbursement for the remaining 50% of providers outside of the 
model.
Model should be VOLUNTARY
o Providers should not collect the drug copay from patients
 Will cause significant administrative burden
 How will the providers pay CMS/vendors for drug copay?
o Providers should not pay the vendors for distribution services
 Providers do not pay for those services under current model
 CMS should pay the vendors for their services

title: WY

commentText:
We strongly oppose the administrations Advanced Notice of Proposed Rule Making (ANPRM) to create an International Pricing Index (IPI) payment model for drugs administered under Medicare Part B.

This proposed payment model effectively imports foreign price controls into the U.S. by modifying the Part B reimbursement rate so that it is calculated based on the prices set by 14 countries.  To make matters worse, many of these fourteen countries effectively steal the intellectual property of American pharmaceutical companies. So importing their pricing systems is effectively importing their theft.  American law and public policy should not reward, encourage or involve the United States dealing in stolen goods.  Yet that is what the proposed rule would do.

Medicare Part B is currently calculated based on market prices negotiated in the United States and include the discounts negotiated between large payers like health plans and hospitals. This system as recently lead to a 0.8 percent decrease in the cost of the top 50 Part B drugs.

In stark contrast, foreign countries frequently impose arbitrary, market-distorting price controls.  In many of these nations, there is no true negotiation. Instead, governments force innovators to accept whatever price the government is willing to offer as a condition of being able to sell any medicine in the country and in some cases the governments will threaten to steal the intellectual property of the pharmaceutical company if they dont agree to strict price controls.

Imagine youre met in a dark parking lot by a masked negotiator who points a gun at you and demands that you sell him your car.  Do you think you will get a fair price if this is how the negotiations proceed?  Or are you just being robbed?  That is how some of these "negotiations with foreign nations go. They are not true at arms length negotiations. It is a horrible idea to legitimize these tactics by basing American prices on these sorts of pricing regimes.

We have long opposed price controls. They distort the marketplace. They distort behavior, reduce incentives, and harm economic efficiency.  One of the biggest problems is that price controls will suppress and reduce innovation in new medicines. If capital doesnt flow to fund research and development of new medications, in the future, we will be limited to medicines that currently exist and further advances and innovations will dramatically slow. Slowing the development and supply of new life saving and life improving medicines will harm consumers and especially those who may suffer from life threatening illnesses in the future.

The United States has been the worlds leader in research and development because our current system rejects price controls and our system of patents encourages and incentivizes innovation. It is no surprise that the vast majority of new medicines are developed and launched in the United States. There is no good reason to endanger or threaten this innovation or this progress. One of costs of this proposal is that with fewer new medicines being developed, we will not see cost savings that are often found in new medicines and treatments. Nor will we see the improved quality of life that comes from these cures and treatments.

Suppressing innovation and harming American competitiveness is bad public policy. Yet that is precisely what this proposal will do. If we adopt this policy, there will be many Americans who will suffer and die of diseases that could have been treated and cured, but for this policy. We now see many forms of cancer that can be treated and cured. But had this policy been adopted twenty or thirty years ago, the current progress weve seen in treating cancer would not be available. So the government cannot simply look at the cost on a per pill basis. It must consider the tremendous human and economic costs that will be imposed if we stifle innovation.

We are also troubled by the use of the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation (CMMI) which was created by Obamacare.  The CMMI bypasses important constitutional protections and requirements. CMMI was created to bypass Congress power of the purse as required in Article I of the U.S. Constitution.  Thus, even if this proposal had merit  which it does not  using the unconstitutional CMMI mechanism is the wrong way to accomplish these goals. 

Frontiers of Freedom and our millions of supporters and members requests that your department withdraw this misguided proposal. This proposal codifies foreign price controls and illegal theft of intellectual property rights. It also suppresses competition and innovation and will harm investment in medical research and leave future patients dependent on currently available medicines, but without the hope of new and innovative medicines. This is bad policy that no reasonable person can support.

title: DC

commentText:
I am very excited about the potential of this regulation. As clearly stated, the United States pays quite high prices for drugs that are available internationally for less, and this issue adds to the high costs of healthcare in the United States.1 If drugs are available for less and we could save as a country, tapping into the international market could really help our cost issue over the long term while also creating relationships with partner countries. While the benefits are clear, I am concerned about some of the implementation plans. 
	The first concern is centered around idea of private vendors creating market competition by distributing drugs straight to the physicians and hospitals while also taking the responsibility of billing Medicare as well. While it is exciting that a physician or hospital will not need to maintain their inventory, I am concerned about the continued lack of price transparency as private vendors would own the process of distributing and coordinating payment of drugs. Furthermore, this relationship that these private vendors would create seem similar to a wholesaler. For a wholesaler to gain benefits, someone would have to bear the cost of their provision of distribution and coordination of payment from Medicare. To me, this seems as if the cost shifts from high drug prices to a middle party in the supply chain of drug delivery. The availability of international pricing dating is an area of concern. Without a way to monitor how these private vendors are truly impacting the costs associated with drug acquisition and delivery, I believe it would be necessary to temper excitement around the international pricing index initiative.
	Additionally, if the providers and physicians are no longer needing to stock their drugs, how will the cost of more frequent deliveries be addressed. More deliveries could result in higher costs, and potentially leave room for patient safety issues, as providers may not have enough of a drug stocked for emergencies. There is room for concern that the cost of both of these could fall on providers and hospitals. 
	Another issue would be around the revenue impact on hospitals and providers. The Common Wealth Fund states that, Medicare would replace its current administrative payment to physicians and hospitals with a flat fee.2 Furthermore, under the current payment structure, providers also are paid a percentage of the drug price under Part B.2 One can only imagine how much impact this would cause providers and hospitals as they do not have the ability to charge for drug administration. To think about how this issue compounds as one considers how many patients are receiving drugs intravenously at the hospital daily is quite concerning as well. Many hospitals are already struggling financially and this regulation may compound the issue as they do not have the opportunity to recoup some costs associated with administering high cost drugs. 
	While understanding that competition helps lowering the cost of drugs to the patient, there should be a fear around what that means for other players in the story. As mentioned earlier, I believe the relationship these private vendors have could result in lower prices, but with no system set up to provide transparency of these prices, how are other players, such as the provider or payer, able to understand if competition is actually in their favor. Furthermore, in the country now, there is no standard price set for any of these services or drugs as pricing is so market dependent. Are these measurement mechanisms going to require significant cost data from hospitals now to understand the impact transitioning to this new pricing index? In my experience as a provider based healthcare consultant, many facilities struggle with cost reporting especially centered around drugs and other pharmaceuticals so standard drug financials may not be available on a widespread national level.
	All concerns stated, I do appreciate the consideration of this new regulation, but I believe there must be a strong focus on transparency to allow for appropriate tracking of impact to provide focus on the task at hand: lowering the cost of drugs to patients while continuing to provide high level healthcare to our citizens. 

Reference:
1.	Beaton, Thomas. "New Drug Pricing Model Could Save Medicare Part B $17.2 Billion." Health Payer Intelligence, healthpayerintelligence.com/news/ new-drug-pricing-model-could-save-medicare-part-b-17.2-billion.
2.	"HHS Proposes to Link Medicare Part B Payment for Prescription Drugs to International Price." To the Point: Quick Takes on Healthcare Policy and Practice, 26 Oct. 2018, www.commonwealthfund.org/ blog/2018/medicare-part-b-payment-prescription-drugs-international-prices.

commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program.

This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. title: GA

commentText: 1. The addition of another mode of drug distribution that is only used for Medicare beneficiaries injects increased complexity into an already complex system.  Health systems would now not only have to deal with insurance company mandates such as "white bagging" from a particular specialty pharmacy, but also this new system for Medicare patients.  The assumption that these intermediaries would in fact save money for Medicare and beneficiaries has not been born out by the current use of PBMs.   The fixed reimbursement model could be applied without changing the distribution system, reducing the perceived incentive to prescribe more expensive drugs.  The proposal ignores the primary source of increased drug prices which is drug manufacturers.  Medicare does not have a formulary or review the cost justification of new and expensive therapies.  Comparing US prices for drugs to the prices in other countries that review new therapies and evaluate incremental clinical value vs. cost, is not a fair comparison.  The proposal also does not take into account how the savings reduced payment to 340B hospitals for outpatient drugs would compare to the new model.  CMS continues to focus its cost reduction strategies on reducing payments to caregivers and ignoring the source of increasing drug costs. There has been no corresponding reduction in regulation, billing complexity, or quality requirements. Record numbers of hospitals are closing their doors in America, especially in rural areas.  Drug companies, PBMs and even these new "intermediaries" cannot take care of patients.  CMS continues to punish the easiest target due to a lack of courage to address the real cause of drug prices.

title: WA

commentText:
Dear Administrator Verma:

On behalf of the National Infusion Center Association (NICA), the hundreds of thousands of patients across the nation requiring provider-administered parenteral medications, and the infusion providers that treat them, I am pleased to submit comments in response to the Administrations advance notice of proposed rulemaking. NICA is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit patient advocacy organization formed to ensure that our nations sickest and most vulnerable patients can access in-office infusion and injectable medications.

There are many complex, multi-faceted challenges facing the sustainability of our health care system. Specialty medications, particularly biological products, are incredibly expensive and list prices for these drugs continue to increase, translating to increased out-of-pocket (OOP) costs for patients and increased cost burden on payers. 

Biological products are used to manage some of the most expensive conditions (e.g., autoimmune diseases, cancer), for which patients are subjected to extraordinary economic burden of disease and high OOP costs. Without access to these medications, the economic burden of disease increases as more health care services are consumed to manage symptoms of disease. If the list prices for biologics continue to increase, patients OOP costs will continue to rise while shifts in benefit plan design continue to produce insurance plans with reduced coverage at higher premiums. If health care and insurance coverage are unaffordable for those that need it most, eventually no one will be able to afford either.

NICA supports the administrations goals to reduce out-of-pocket costs for Medicare beneficiaries, increase access, and improve adherence. However, there is great concern that increasing complexity in the Part B program by introducing more middlemen into the drug supply chain, increasing infusion providers administrative burden, and reducing providers payments may not achieve these goals. Particularly with a mandatory demonstration that would affect half of the Part B program and influence the medical benefit drug market beyond the scope of the demonstration.

NICA submits comments to bring the following concerns to the administrations attention:
	Reform measures that restrict, delay, or disrupt access to care may increase cost burden, produce sub-optimal health outcomes, and adversely impact quality of life. 
	Mandatory participation in a demonstration may jeopardize the sustainability of physician practices, adversely reshape the delivery channel, and disrupt patients access to care; 
	Shifting the Part B drug supply chain to be less patient-centric would not in the best interest of the vulnerable patient populations relying on the Part B program; and,
	There may be strategies to achieve the goals outlined in the advanced notice of proposed rulemaking that are less complex and less disruptive. 

Please see attached comments letter.

commentText:
December 27, 2018

Via Federal eRulemaking Portal: http://www.regulations.gov

Seema Verma
Administrator
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services 
Department of Health and Human Services
P.O. Box 8013
Baltimore, MD 21244-8013

Re: 	CMS-5528-ANPRM
	Comments on CMS Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking International Pricing Index Model for Medicare Part B Drugs 

Dear Administrator Verma:

Marshall County Healthcare Center Avera appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking ("Advanced Notice") regarding the International Pricing Index (IPI) Model for Medicare Part B Drugs.  Marshall County Healthcare Center Avera is a critical access hospital (CAH) that participates in the 340B program by virtue of providing safety net services to individuals located in rural and remote locations in the United States. CAHs face significant financial challenges and often struggle to keep their doors open. In fact, 90 rural hospitals have closed since 2010.  

We applaud the Administration's efforts to address the issue of high drug prices. CMS appears to be focused on using the IPI Model to test changes in payment for drugs that are currently paid by Medicare Part B based on average sales price (ASP). CMS intends for the IPI Model to incentivize providers to seek out lower costs for drugs and reduce inappropriate utilization by changing the add-on payment for drugs paid based on ASP. However, CMS has solicited feedback on whether to include CAHs in the IPI Model. Medicare recognizes that CAHs are unique and pays CAHs based on costs, not ASP. As providers that are not paid based on ASP, CMS does not need to include CAHs in the model to achieve its goals. For this reason and given the unique patient populations that we treat, and the challenges rural patients could face in accessing care if our hospital were included in the model, we ask that CMS exclude CAHs from the model. 



In addition, we are concerned that including our hospital in the IPI Model could limit our patients access to Part B drugs or disrupt their treatment. For example, model vendors could restrict how hospitals order drugs by requiring hospitals to submit patient and/or prescription information prior to shipping the drugs, limiting which hospital locations are able to receive drug shipments, or limiting the amount of inventory hospitals are able to access in advance of patient treatment. Such disruptions to the distribution system could also increase white/brown bagging practices, which could lead to drug safety and efficacy issues for patients. This impact would be especially problematic for our patients who may need to travel significant distances to receive care. For example, Avera Health is a rural healthcare system that spans over a four state area.  We try to help local patients receive services and infusions closer to home at their rural hospitals when working with specialty physicians within the Avera Health system to improve patient care and minimize patient travel time and costs.   


Participating in the IPI Model would also create operational burdens that could affect our ability to treat patients. Model participants would need to track model drugs given to Part B patients, which would require the creation of a manual process or investment in software to track model drugs. These operational burdens would be especially challenging for 340B hospitals, which already operate complex management systems to manage 340B and non-340B drug inventories. Imposing additional inventory tracking requirements on 340B hospitals would strain our scarce resources and further limit our ability to treat rural patients. 

We appreciate the opportunity to provide comments on this Advanced Notice. For the reasons outlined above, we respectfully urge CMS to exclude CAHs from the IPI Model.

Sincerely,

Marshall County Healthcare Center Avera

commentText:
December 17, 2018

Attn: Secretary Alex Azar
U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
200 Independence Avenue, S.W.
Washington, D.C. 20201


Dear Secretary Azar,

Texas growing economy is linked with our states robust biopharmaceutical sector, providing innovations in biomedical science, biotechnology and medical devices that help patients lead longer, healthier lives. Unfortunately, this progress is threatened by the announced Medicare Part B demonstration through the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS). This proposal stands to change the very foundations of Medicare Part B, limiting patient choice and perversely impacting the development of new medications.

This broad, mandatory demonstration would have a significant impact on what patients have access to in the Part B program, including inhibiting access to groundbreaking, innovative therapies even if they represent the best course of treatment for patients individual needs. While these changes are nominally an effort to reduce program costs, limiting patients access to potentially more effective treatments could result in the contrary as conditions remain inadequately managed and additional health care interventions are required.

Concerning to the Texas biopharmaceutical industry is the potentially chilling effect that this proposal may have on research and development (R&D) operations across the state. Today, biopharmaceutical innovators support a total of 228,353 jobs statewide. Each year, Texas has reaped an estimated $61.5 billion in economic output from our industry. This contribution, in addition to the nearly $3 billion in annual personal taxes from sector employees, helps fund programs across the state  supporting initiatives in education, infrastructure and public health. The proposed demonstration would dissuade investment in this industry.

The broader economic and industry consequences must be taken into account by CMS, but the worst effects will inevitably fall on Medicare Part B beneficiaries. Part B helps serve some of the most critically ill patient populations, who often live with serious conditions. R&D and the steady discovery of new treatments provides hope for these individuals. 

Patients and Texans deserve better than this proposal. Any changes to our health care system must take into account the need to provide patients, their providers and families the maximum amount of choices when it comes to their treatment decisions. This can be accomplished through reducing access barriers to new treatment, allowing doctors to prescribe the best possible care for patients without bureaucratic interference. The future of health care and our economy is on display in Texas each day. To protect and preserve these advances for future generations, the Department of Health and Human Services must withdraw this harmful demonstration before it goes into effect.

Sincerely,

Tom Kowalski
President and CEO
Texas Healthcare and Bioscience Institute


cc: Texas Congressional Delegation Members
