commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

title: AL

commentText:
Secretary Alex Azar 
U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
200 Independence Avenue, S.W.
Washington, D.C. 20201

Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services
Department of Health and Human Services
Attention: CMS-5528-ANPRM
P.O. Box 8013
Baltimore, MD 21244-8013.

Dear Secretary Azar,

The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) recently announced demonstration, which fundamentally alters the Medicare Part B program, is deeply concerning to Colorados seniors. 

This widespread experiment may alter the coverage and current treatment regimens of an estimated 64 percent of Colorado Medicare beneficiaries, as well as, restrict patient access to innovative medications while fostering a hostile economic environment for providers.

A key to the Part B programs success has always been the critical relationship between patients and their health care providers. Keeping this relationship localized and personal helps ensure that treatment is tailored to the needs of the patient.

It is estimated, however, that the changes proposed by CMS would threaten 150 practices across Colorado by creating additional barriers between patients and the individualized care they have come to expect from the Part B program. To put that in context, thats nearly 84 percent of the oncology, hematology, and rheumatology practices in our state. Denial of care based on an arbitrary international pricing index, the creation of new bureaucratic middlemen, or changes to providers reimbursements are a prescription for poorer health care outcomes for seniors.

Our concerns are even more magnified when it comes to the impact this proposal would have on community clinics in the more rural parts of Colorado. Older Coloradans should not have to drive hours to see the providers they need to see to managed their health and negative changes to Part B reimbursement could threaten the survival of small, independent clinics that are already dwindling in number.

Ensuring seniors have access to the critical health care services and treatments administered under the Medicare Part B program is vital to preserving their quality of life and continued engagement in our communities. Older Coloradans already face significant obstacles receiving adequate, high-quality care due to mobility issues and fixed budgets. This widespread demonstration only serves to compound those concerns by narrowing seniors options and placing innovative, potentially life-saving treatments out-of-reach.

More broadly, the biopharmaceutical R&D sector in Colorado provides significant economic growth and opportunity for our state. Its estimated this sector supports 56,869 jobs across Colorado, both directly and indirectly, generating $13.7 billion in economic output. This demonstration may put those jobs at risk as well, creating potentially negative downstream effects for our state.

Ultimately, the Part B demonstrations widespread, mandatory experimentation in the existing care and treatments of Colorados senior populations may unintentionally exacerbate the very health concerns the program was designed to curb. Unfortunately, this proposed demonstration does not take into account patient needs, or the economic realities of providers and innovators across our state.

For the health and wellbeing of seniors, and Colorado at large, we call on the Department of Health and Human Services to formally withdraw their proposed demonstration. Preserving seniors access to the exceptional medications and therapies covered under the Part B program must remain a guiding principle for our representatives and leaders. This proposal falls short of that goal.
Sincerely,

 
Eileen Doherty 
Colorado Gerontological Society
Executive Director

commentText:
I am writing about my concern as a Rheumatologist regarding the Medicare program  proposed for part B drugs. I am opposed to the program/"experiment" that would potentially affect half of practicing physician. I do not believe it is fair or ethical that arbitrarily, half of medicare patients would lose access to life improving medications.
Additionally much the small percentage (4.3%) above ASP that we are paid for purchasing and administering medications goes into over head costs such as nursing, IT,  procurement and storage of medications, office staff to schedule and service these patients.
If this model goes into place many physician will not find it financially feasible to continue administering these necessary medications to our patients. Myself and many doctors may have to either opt-out of Medicare in which case large numbers of patients will lose access to care and have to seek out care elsewhere. Or, many physician may be forced to turn these patients to hospitals or hospital owned infusion centers which will cost CMS exponentially more (you must realize hospitals are reimbursed on a separate schedule than outpatient practices, which is much more)
Also, our Medicare patients are on these medications because Part D does not cover these expensive meds, so they will be left without options for treatment or have to find a way to pay out of pocket for the deductables, donut hole expenses, etc.. which will overall increase the cost of care for patients many of which who do not have the means to pay for it.
I also find it disheartening that you go after the low hanging fruit which is doctors. We do not dictate the price of our medications. I know there are always exeptions, but by in large we are honest and hard working doctors who's priority is to do what is best for our patients and provide the best care we can despite the cost. The small amount you pay above ASP to administer these medications does not incentive us to use them and I believe is a small part of your total expenditure. You should focus on the price drivers who are pharma, retail pharmacies, PBM's, and specialty pharmacies. These entities are making billions of profit here, yet you are focused on the ones delivering the appropriate care. 
I can appreciate your effort in trying to lower the cost of medicines and medical care but I hope you take into consideration these concerns as well as others thoughtful opinions in these comments.
Thank you
title: Tim Howard, PA

commentText: I oppose any idea or plan by the federal government to impose any type of price controls on prescription drugs. Aside from the fact that it would possibly  be un-Constitutional under the takings clause in the 5th Amendment, it could also prove catastrophically harmful to future pharmaceutical research and development. We had the greatest health care system in the world prior to the Affordable Care Act, and despite the problems that have arisen from said act, we still have a very good health care system. Further attempts to regulate it will only prove to further erode the efficacy, ingenuity, and resourcefulness of those supporting the industry. Most of the pharmaceutical companies already offer assistance to patients who are economically disadvantaged and cannot afford their medications, so any attempt to set price controls is looking for a solution to a problem that has already been solved.

commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

commentText:
Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (Regeneron) appreciates the opportunity to respond to the Advance Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (ANPRM) for the Medicare Program; International Pricing Index (IPI) Model for Medicare Part B Drugs (the Advance Notice).  

Regeneron is a leading U.S. biotechnology company that invents life-transforming medicines for people with serious diseases and is committed to consistently and repeatedly bringing new medicines to patients with serious diseases. Founded and led for 30 years by physician-scientists dedicated to fostering a science-driven, patient-centered mission, Regeneron has developed a unique ability to translate science into medicine consistently which has led to seven FDA-approved treatments and 20 product candidates in clinical development across multiple therapeutic areas, all of which were homegrown in our laboratories. Our medicines and pipeline are designed to help patients with conditions such as eye disease, heart disease, allergic and inflammatory diseases, pain, cancer, infectious diseases and rare diseases.  Regeneron is accelerating and improving the traditional drug development process through its proprietary VelociSuite technologies and ambitious initiatives such as the Regeneron Genetics Center, one of the largest genetics sequencing efforts in the world.  As a testament to these capabilities, we have a robust partnership with the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA) to develop Ebola and influenza treatments.  We are a company that has been listed for five consecutive years in Forbes Most Innovative Companies and received many other prestigious accolades.  We are passionate about our home-grown science and the patients we serve.

For nearly 30 years, Regenerons goal has been to use the power of science to bring new medicines to patients over and over again. We have fostered and maintained a long-term focus on bringing innovation to patients by investing our resources back into research and development of new technologies and therapies, and by pricing our products responsibly and ethically. In 2017, we invested approximately 35% of our revenue into research and development. 
In the Advance Notice, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) states that it intends to test a model that: (1) phases down the Medicare payment amount for selected Part B drugs and biologics to more closely align with international prices; (2) allows private-sector vendors to negotiate prices for drugs, take title to drugs, compete for physician and hospital business and offer a variety of delivery options; and (3) creates a bonus pool of funding for providers that would redistribute the previously established 6 percent add-on payment to cover  the costs of drug ordering, storage, and handling as performance incentives.

Like the Administration and others, we are committed to improving access and affordability and advancing scientific discovery and inventions to improve the lives of American patients. We agree with several goals of the IPI model as outlined in this Advance Notice.  However, we urge the Administration to consider several factors as it seeks to improve beneficiaries quality of care, lower cost-sharing, and address foreign free-riding including measures to: 
	Maintain and improve patients access to life-transforming therapies;
	Reduce the burden of changes on providers; 
	Exempt U.S. innovator companies products from the model when the innovator does not have control over ex-U.S. pricing;
	Ensure robust U.S. innovation in biologic therapies and associated economic gains; and  
	Minimize flaws that could render the IPI model unfeasible or sustainable in the long-term. 

At minimum, the proposal should ensure that the demonstration project: (1) maintains meaningful physician and patient access to the best treatment option for a patients given condition; and (2) does not penalize U.S. innovator companies which do not control ex-US prices for a particular drug.  Set forth below is a more detailed discussion of specific concerns and recommendations.  We respectfully request that CMS consider these recommendations before it adopts any changes to the current Medicare Part B coverage and payment program for prescription drugs and biologics.  

We look forward to working with the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and other stakeholders to identify solutions that will improve affordability, access, and ensure that U.S. innovator biotechnology companies can continue to invent new life-transforming medicines, increase the numbers of U.S.  jobs and contribute to a robust U.S. economy.

commentText:
Celgene Corporation (Celgene) appreciates the opportunity to respond to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) International Pricing Index (IPI) Model for Medicare Part B Drugs.

Celgene is a global biopharmaceutical company specializing in the discovery, development, and delivery of therapies designed to treat cancer and inflammatory and immunological conditions.  Celgene strongly believes that medical innovation can lead to better health, longer life, reduced disability, and greater prosperity for patients and our nation.  To this end, we seek to deliver truly innovative and life-changing therapies for the patients we serve. We are currently engaged in 160 clinical trials with 42 novel medicines across 60 indications. In 2017, we reinvested 45.5% of our revenue into research and development to discover and develop the therapies of tomorrow.
 
Celgene strongly supports the Administrations efforts to ensure that all patients have affordable access to the care they need. As committed as Celgene is to discovering and developing new treatments, we are equally committed to patient support and access to those medical advances  a guiding principle for our company. We believe all who can benefit from our discoveries should have the opportunity to do so. Celgene focuses on putting patients first with programs that provide information, support and access to our innovative therapies. 

However, we are deeply concerned that the IPI model, as proposed, would reduce patient access to Part B drugs. Rather than promote market-based negotiation, a goal that we and many other stakeholders support, the proposed demonstration would import price controls from countries that restrict patient access as a cost control mechanism. Ultimately, the IPI model would restrict patient access, increase complexity in the physician-administered drug distribution system and significantly disrupt Medicare providers. 

Patients in the U.S. continue to struggle with burdensome out-of-pocket costs, including in the Part B program. We share HHSs frustration that other countries impose price controls and restrict access for patients. However, we respectfully encourage HHS to focus on policy solutions that will help American patients by leveraging market-based competition to reduce out-of-pocket costs, improve access and adherence and lower health system costs.

We strongly urge CMS to withdraw the IPI model in its entirety and continue working with a range of health system stakeholders to develop policy solutions that will enhance competition, strengthen market-based negotiations and promote patient access across insurance markets. Our detailed comments on the IPI model are included in the attached letter. In addition, we refer to the comments submitted by the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America and Biotechnology Innovation Organization, which contain additional supporting evidence for many of the points raised in our letter.

commentText:
December 27, 2018

Via Federal eRulemaking Portal: http://www.regulations.gov

Seema Verma
Administrator
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services 
Department of Health and Human Services
P.O. Box 8013
Baltimore, MD 21244-8013

Re: 	Comments on CMS Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking International Pricing Index Model for Medicare Part B Drugs (CMS-5528-ANPRM)

Dear Administrator Verma:

Avera St. Marys Hospital appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking ("Advanced Notice") regarding the International Pricing Index (IPI) Model for Medicare Part B Drugs. Our hospital participates in the 340B drug pricing program, which has provided safety-net hospitals relief from high drug costs since the program's enactment in 1992. While we applaud the Administration's commitment to addressing the issue of high drug prices, we are concerned about the potential unintended implications for the 340B program, patient access to treatment, and increased burden on hospital operations. Given that the 340B program has a record of reducing drug costs over the last 26 years, we request that CMS preserve the 340B discount.

CMS Should Preserve the 340B Discount 

The 340B program requires certain manufacturers to provide discounts on drugs sold to safety net providers, including hospitals, that meet strict eligibility criteria. The discount is intended to allow those providers to stretch their resources to provide more comprehensive services to more patients. Because the proposed IPI model eliminates the ability of hospitals to buy drugs for Medicare Part B patients, manufacturers would no longer be required to reduce their prices. We question the value of removing this established and proven method of reducing drug prices charged to safety net providers and strongly recommend that it be maintained, rather than eliminated for a proposal that may not achieve the same level of savings as are achieved under the 340B program.

We urge CMS to retain the 340B discount model, since it is an established and proven method for reducing drug prices, by excluding 340B hospitals from the IPI Model. 

We also request that CMS make clear that the model vendors would not constitute group purchasing arrangements for 340B purposes. Since many 340B hospitals are prohibited from using such arrangements, failure to clarify this issue could eliminate our ability to obtain 340B discounts for drugs purchased outside the model, thereby terminating our ability to access 340B discounts for any drugs we purchase, even those outside the model and outside of Medicare.  

CMS Should Consider the Impact of the IPI Model on Patient Access and Hospital Operations

We are concerned that the IPI Model could limit our patients access to Part B drugs or disrupt their treatment. For example, model vendors could restrict how hospitals order drugs, by requiring hospitals to submit patient and/or prescription information prior to shipping the drugs, limiting which hospital locations are able to receive drug shipments, or limiting the amount of inventory hospitals are able to access in advance of patient treatment. Such disruptions to the distribution system could interfere with or delay patient access to treatment and could also increase white/brown bagging practices, which could lead to drug safety and efficacy issues for patients. This impact would be especially problematic for our hospital's patients, given that we treat high volumes of low-income patients who often do not have other options to receive care. 

The IPI Model could also create operational burdens affecting our ability to treat patients. Model participants would need to track model drugs given to Part B patients, requiring the creation of a manual process or investment in software to track model drugs. These operational burdens would be especially challenging for 340B hospitals, which already operate complex management systems to manage 340B and non-340B drug inventories. Imposing additional inventory tracking requirements on 340B hospitals would strain our scarce resources and further limit our ability to treat low-income patients. These concerns further support our request that 340B hospitals be excluded from the IPI Model.

We appreciate the opportunity to provide comments on this Advanced Notice. For the reasons outlined above, we respectfully urge CMS to preserve the 340B discount. 

Sincerely,

Avera St. Marys Hospital

title: DC

commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.
title: KY

commentText:
I am writing to ask that you reject socialist agendas. Socialism is a destructive economic system that destroys countries and people everywhere it's tried. In the medical world,  if this regulation is enacted, itll force American companies to obey socialist price controls on prescription drugs like the ones in France and Sweden.
This will stop the development of potentially life-saving medicines and limit patients access to medication by decreasing supplies.
 
The reason the cost of medicine is so high already in this country is because of government subsidies and involvement that permit insurance companies and drug companies to charge whatever they want and get away with it, knowing government through Medicare and Medicaid will always foot the bill. So prices are always driven higher. We need government to get out of the medical business and for competition to take place. This is especially true with regard to permitting people and companies to purchase health insurance across state lines and frankly, from anywhere they want. Such competition would quickly bring prices down across the board.

commentText:
This is unfortunate. Trump's plan to decrease Medicare drug prices would discourage innovation for pharmaceutical companies. For rheumatology practices, there would be increased burden, payer requirements for prior authorizations, drug administration, step edits, cost-sharing and detailed documentation. It would also affect patient access to new personalized options. Around the world, America is regarded as the researchers/innovators with unparalleled access to care. Socialized medicine limits access to new drugs as evidenced by the Australian and European formularies. Trump plan is against American sentiment in that way.
A solution could be to put caps on PBM drug pricing or encourage American providers to pursue lower price drug algorithms prior to higher priced drugs. This would reduce cost without restricting access or innovation.

commentText: University of Virginia Health System (UVAHS) appreciate the opportunity to comment on the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (ANPRM) regarding the International Pricing Index (IPI) Model for Medicare Part B Drugs.  While we applaud the Administration's commitment to addressing the issue of high drug prices, we are concerned about the potential unintended implications of the ANPRMs model on the 340B program, our patients access to treatment, and increased administrative and operational burdens to our health system.  Given the 340B program has a record of reducing drug costs over the last 26 years, we request CMS to preserve and maintain the 340B discount by excluding 340B hospitals from the IPI model and allowing 340B eligible providers to continue to purchase drugs at the 340B discount from drug manufacturers for Medicare beneficiaries and our other patients.

title: NJ

commentText:
December 27, 2018

Via Federal eRulemaking Portal: http://www.regulations.gov

Seema Verma
Administrator
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services 
Department of Health and Human Services
P.O. Box 8013
Baltimore, MD 21244-8013

Re: 	CMS-5528-ANPRM
	Comments on CMS Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking International Pricing Index Model for Medicare Part B Drugs 

Dear Administrator Verma:

Pipestone County Medical Center appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking ("Advanced Notice") regarding the International Pricing Index (IPI) Model for Medicare Part B Drugs.  Pipestone County Medical Center is a critical access hospital (CAH) that participates in the 340B program by virtue of providing safety net services to individuals located in rural and remote locations in the United States. CAHs face significant financial challenges and often struggle to keep their doors open. In fact, 90 rural hospitals have closed since 2010.  

We applaud the Administration's efforts to address the issue of high drug prices. CMS appears to be focused on using the IPI Model to test changes in payment for drugs that are currently paid by Medicare Part B based on average sales price (ASP). CMS intends for the IPI Model to incentivize providers to seek out lower costs for drugs and reduce inappropriate utilization by changing the add-on payment for drugs paid based on ASP. However, CMS has solicited feedback on whether to include CAHs in the IPI Model. Medicare recognizes that CAHs are unique and pays CAHs based on costs, not ASP. As providers that are not paid based on ASP, CMS does not need to include CAHs in the model to achieve its goals. For this reason and given the unique patient populations that we treat, and the challenges rural patients could face in accessing care if our hospital were included in the model, we ask that CMS exclude CAHs from the model. 



In addition, we are concerned that including our hospital in the IPI Model could limit our patients access to Part B drugs or disrupt their treatment. For example, model vendors could restrict how hospitals order drugs by requiring hospitals to submit patient and/or prescription information prior to shipping the drugs, limiting which hospital locations are able to receive drug shipments, or limiting the amount of inventory hospitals are able to access in advance of patient treatment. Such disruptions to the distribution system could also increase white/brown bagging practices, which could lead to drug safety and efficacy issues for patients. This impact would be especially problematic for our patients who may need to travel significant distances to receive care. For example, Avera Health is a rural healthcare system that spans over a four state area.  We try to help local patients receive services and infusions closer to home at their rural hospitals when working with specialty physicians within the Avera Health system to improve patient care and minimize patient travel time and costs.   


Participating in the IPI Model would also create operational burdens that could affect our ability to treat patients. Model participants would need to track model drugs given to Part B patients, which would require the creation of a manual process or investment in software to track model drugs. These operational burdens would be especially challenging for 340B hospitals, which already operate complex management systems to manage 340B and non-340B drug inventories. Imposing additional inventory tracking requirements on 340B hospitals would strain our scarce resources and further limit our ability to treat rural patients. 

We appreciate the opportunity to provide comments on this Advanced Notice. For the reasons outlined above, we respectfully urge CMS to exclude CAHs from the IPI Model.

Sincerely,

Pipestone County Medical Center

commentText:
As a private practice rheumatologist, I appreciate the opportunity to comment on this ANPRM. I am excited to see CMS attempting to address drug pricing. As a physician who buys and bills infusible part B drugs for rheumatic diseases, I am sad to see the continual rise in drug prices. However, I chafe at the notion as stated in the ANPRM that I would prescribe more expensive part B drugs due to ASP+4.3 financial incentives. When a patient with severe RA needs a biologic, the cost differential between the various biologics is small enough that there is no rationale for drug cost to guide a decision (they are all about equally expensive). Right now, we have no cheaper biologic drugs, though we hope the era of biosimilars will change this. If CMS wants to impact drug costs meaningfully, accelerate the arrival of biosimilars to our market. I have switched most of my Medicare Remicade patients to the biosimilar for cost savings to the patient and the system.
In the current model, there are 2 middlemen, the drug distributor and the physician. I dont know what the distributor's margin is between their purchase and sale to me.  My margin is approximately 4.3%.  The fact that CMS model drops one middleman should alone provide cost savings. Physicians fall into 2 categories, those who are comfortable with the financial risk of obtaining title to drugs, such as myself, and those who are not. Those who are not, are likely not infusing drugs in office, and may be sending patients to hospital outpatient infusion centers, which are more expensive. Giving those providers an option to administer drugs in their office without financial risk, could be a winner for all parties. For those of us willing to take financial risk, with efficient outpatient infusion models which save CMS money by keeping patients out of hospital settings, allow us the opportunity to become vendors, as you mention as a potential option in your ANPRM.  If you allow me to become a vendor who can obtain drug from the manufacturer, while at the same time reducing the reimbursement from ASP+6 to an IPI model, the manufacturer will have to provide me the drug at a reasonable cost(which is lower than the current drug cost) or lose my business, and in so doing I will still be able to infuse with a margin covering operational costs, and at the same time the overall cost to the system will go down as the total drug cost reduces. I see this as a win win.
A more direct way to accomplish this without disrupting the system, would be to allow Medicare to negotiate drug prices in part B, and then we could still obtain our drugs and treat our patients as we currently do, but the total drug cost would be less (ie, if you tell UCB the reimbursement for Cimzia is now going to be 20% less, Im pretty sure theyll sell me the drug for 20% less if they want to keep my business). I am unsure I would participate in a model with 100% pass through drug cost, as it would not cover my infusion space rent, infusion nurse, full time staff for prior auths, etc. I would send the patients to a hospital outpatient infusion, where they would spend more time, be exposed to sick patients, and the total cost to the system would likely be higher.
If CMS chooses to move forward with this model, the main thrust of my comments above is to allow options that serves both the risk averse and the risk-willing physician. Your notice implies that physicians and hospitals are risk averse to obtaining title to drugs, but this is only true for some.  Allow a neutral vendor to provide drug to those who are risk averse. Please fully develop the model you mention that allows physician to be direct vendors, without excessive red tape. If you limit the definition of vendor to a complicated algorithm or add red tape that only the current major distributors (CVS Caremark, McKesson, etc) can fulfill, many patients and providers will be left out in the cold. Specifically in response to the question in section III.a.1-2 in the ANPRM, making CMS a party to any agreement between parties in the distribution would likely add enough red tape to make it non-workable. If you allow a physician or group of physicians to become vendors, there is no logical reason to require them to serve as a national distributor( iii.a.2). Why not allow the current larger vendors to serve this role, and allow smaller physician groups or GPOs to obtain the drugs for their own practices directly from manufacturers?  In regards to billing and collections as per section iii.a.6, why would it make sense for my staff, whom I am paying, to expend resources to collect co payments on behalf of a neutral drug provider with whom I do not have a financial arrangement, and then for me to pay THEM a fee for ME doing that work for them. I would close my infusion clinic first.  This is another reason I would prefer to be the vendor in private practice rather than use a neutral vendor. Thank you for for attention!
title: Chris Phillips, KY

commentText:
December 27, 2018

Via Federal eRulemaking Portal: http://www.regulations.gov

Seema Verma
Administrator
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services 
Department of Health and Human Services
P.O. Box 8013
Baltimore, MD 21244-8013

Re: 	CMS-5528-ANPRM
	Comments on CMS Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking International Pricing Index Model for Medicare Part B Drugs 

Dear Administrator Verma:

Avera St. Benedict Health Center appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking ("Advanced Notice") regarding the International Pricing Index (IPI) Model for Medicare Part B Drugs.  Avera St. Benedict Health Center is a critical access hospital (CAH) that participates in the 340B program by virtue of providing safety net services to individuals located in rural and remote locations in the United States. CAHs face significant financial challenges and often struggle to keep their doors open. In fact, 90 rural hospitals have closed since 2010.  

We applaud the Administration's efforts to address the issue of high drug prices. CMS appears to be focused on using the IPI Model to test changes in payment for drugs that are currently paid by Medicare Part B based on average sales price (ASP). CMS intends for the IPI Model to incentivize providers to seek out lower costs for drugs and reduce inappropriate utilization by changing the add-on payment for drugs paid based on ASP. However, CMS has solicited feedback on whether to include CAHs in the IPI Model. Medicare recognizes that CAHs are unique and pays CAHs based on costs, not ASP. As providers that are not paid based on ASP, CMS does not need to include CAHs in the model to achieve its goals. For this reason and given the unique patient populations that we treat, and the challenges rural patients could face in accessing care if our hospital were included in the model, we ask that CMS exclude CAHs from the model. 



In addition, we are concerned that including our hospital in the IPI Model could limit our patients access to Part B drugs or disrupt their treatment. For example, model vendors could restrict how hospitals order drugs by requiring hospitals to submit patient and/or prescription information prior to shipping the drugs, limiting which hospital locations are able to receive drug shipments, or limiting the amount of inventory hospitals are able to access in advance of patient treatment. Such disruptions to the distribution system could also increase white/brown bagging practices, which could lead to drug safety and efficacy issues for patients. This impact would be especially problematic for our patients who may need to travel significant distances to receive care. For example, Avera Health is a rural healthcare system that spans over a four state area.  We try to help local patients receive services and infusions closer to home at their rural hospitals when working with specialty physicians within the Avera Health system to improve patient care and minimize patient travel time and costs.   


Participating in the IPI Model would also create operational burdens that could affect our ability to treat patients. Model participants would need to track model drugs given to Part B patients, which would require the creation of a manual process or investment in software to track model drugs. These operational burdens would be especially challenging for 340B hospitals, which already operate complex management systems to manage 340B and non-340B drug inventories. Imposing additional inventory tracking requirements on 340B hospitals would strain our scarce resources and further limit our ability to treat rural patients. 

We appreciate the opportunity to provide comments on this Advanced Notice. For the reasons outlined above, we respectfully urge CMS to exclude CAHs from the IPI Model.

Sincerely,

Avera St. Benedict Health Center

title: MS

commentText:
I believe this proposed change is much needed and will get us to the root/core of the problem the fastest...

Lets looks at specialty drug as an example.....Novartis and Gleevec (Imatinib).....a targeted cancer therapy for CML. Gleevec was available exclusively from Novartis for ~20 years (1995-2015)....the pill cost pennies to make...but the cost in the US for a year supply rose from ~$70K/year in the late 1990s to ~$120K/year in 2015...Novartis more than recovered R&D cost - Gleevec became their primary pharma profit engine for the last decade of that patent protection run.....helping to destroy healthcare plans.
 
In 2015, Novartis lost patent protection on Gleevec.....what happened? Generic manufacturers and Novartis lowered the cost to $90K/year - because the US healthcare system is willing to pay it....so, Novartis and the generic manufactures continue to swim in Gleevec profit (for a drug that has zero patent protection - and costs pennies to make). 

You can get the same generic Gleevec now in Canada for ~$6K/year. 

If the US continues to operate as is with Big Pharma - and more and more specialty meds are added to the system - we will have zero chance if stopping runaway healthcare costs..

Big Pharma and biotech startups have gone past the economic point of diminishing returns....they are using the money subsidized by US healthcare plans to fund more and more startups (where 80% fail) - well beyond the point of economic sustainability.

While creating advances in medical biology has indisputable merit, it has to be framed in economic reality (as does any business model).

By implementing this proposed rule, we will address this issue expeditiously at its root - and force Big Pharma to scale back R&D investments that are more in-line with the reality of supporting healthcare system funding - to create a sustainable model for the long-run.

Very much in-favor of this ruling - great work!  Thank You!
title: James Merlotti, MO

title: NC

commentText:
November 16, 2018 

Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
Department of Health and Human Services
P.O. Box 8013
Baltimore, MD  21244-1850

Attention:

CMS-5528-ANPRM
Soliciting public comments on utilizing international price controls in Medicare Part B.

Citizens Against Government Waste (CAGW) is a private, nonpartisan, nonprofit, organization representing more than one million members and supporters nationwide.  CAGWs mission is to eliminate waste, mismanagement, and inefficiency in the federal government.  Founded in 1984 by the late industrialist J. Peter Grace and syndicated columnist Jack Anderson, CAGW was established to follow up on the work of the Presidents Private Sector Survey on Cost Control, also known as the Grace Commission.

For centuries, governments around the world have tried to control the prices of goods and services.  These efforts have disrupted the marketplace and created shortages or excesses.  The Council of Economic Advisers (CEA) wrote in their February 2018 report, Reforming Biopharmaceutical Pricing at Home and Abroad, that foreign governments, which are the primary buyers in their respective pharmaceutical markets, force drug manufacturers to comply with pricing rules to gain market access.  Through this leverage, foreign governments are able to set drug prices below those that prevail in the United States and erode the returns to innovation manufacturers might otherwise see from selling in their markets.

Adopting international price controls is a deeply flawed proposal that has been pushed by many politicians in an erroneous effort to drive down drug costs.  It would run contrary to the deregulatory achievements of the Trump administration, which have saved $23 billion from 176 actions in fiscal year 2018.  Indeed, it could undermine this impressive progress by reversing the growth of government controls over industry and the economy that were rampant throughout the Obama administration.   CAGW urges the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services to abandon the proposed rule and refocus on making other countries pay their fair share of U.S.-financed drug development.

Our complete comments are attached.

Thomas Schatz
President
CAGW
title: Thomas Schatz, DC

commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

ASCP's senior care pharmacist members manage and improve quality of life of geriatric patients and other individuals residing in a variety of environments, including nursing facilities, sub-acute care and assisted living facilities, psychiatric hospitals, hospice programs, and home and community-based care.

We are grateful for the opportunity to comment on this proposed rule and will limit our comments to specific sections of the proposed rule that have special significance to the beneficiaries we serve and relate to the expertise of our profession.
 
ASCP is supportive of efforts to create a more appropriate reimbursement formula for Medicare Part B services, preserve or enhance quality of care and reduce beneficiary cost sharing. However, we have a few areas of concern.

commentText:
Comments on the International Pricing Index Model for Medicare Part B Drugs

Submitted by Hadley Heath Manning to Center for Medicare & Medicaid Services
Director of Policy
Independent Women's Forum

Independent Womens Forum works to advance policies that arent just well-intended but actually enhance freedom, choices, and opportunities for American women, men and families. We have long argued in favor of greater freedom and less government intervention in health care, which would lead to more competition, choice, affordability and access.

The proposed International Pricing Index program is exactly the kind of well-intended policy that concerns us. While we all understand that the high cost of pharmaceutical drugs is a serious problem that needs to be addressed, this proposal comes with downsides that outweigh its benefit of lower drug costs.

Americans depend on drugs to improve, prolong and often even save lives. The type of price control proposed via the IPI would discourage the development of innovative new drugs and could create drug shortages, the kind that are commonplace in countries with socialized government-run medical systems. When needed drugs arent available in hospitals or pharmacies, price doesnt matter. 

Medicare price negotiations  no matter how they are structured  will always face an inherent problem: Medicare is a third-party payer. Taxpayers are interested in keeping costs low, but patients depend on prices being sufficient to pay for the needed research, development, testing and manufacturing to bring drugs to market. 

Its admirable that President Trump and his administration want to lower drug costs, but this proposal would do so in the worst way, imposing blunt price ceilings and ignoring the impact this might have on drug access. 

The problem of high drug costs can only be properly addressed by engaging the private sector, reducing the costs associated with developing and bringing drugs to market whenever possible, promoting market competition, and actually allowing more individual skin in the game through reasonable cost-sharing. This is the opposite approach to price controls, and the only approach that might successfully lower prices without sacrificing access.

title: TN

commentText:
I, as a manager of solo medical oncologist office in Houston, has been struggle in balance with patient care and competitive environment, increasing cost of labor, regulation on USP 800 for the chemotherapy mixing room, high cost of medication.etc

The control of price on Part B medication is definitely a correct action from CMS. As a small office, we do have to struggle to ask for the out of pocket expenses from patients due to high price of medication. Patients are also struggle to pay for the unreasonable price  of medication. Also, we have to fight for the insurance companies which gave us all the unreasonable excuse to try to delay or refuse to pay for the high amount of medication claims, especially those Medicare Advantage plans. 

Its true, for a decent physician, just want to treat patients and dont even want to involve so much on the financial benefit. Thats why we do not have any share on any imaging center or specialty pharmacy like other physicians. 

On the CMS IPI proposal, we do think it is a big step to change the high price of healthcare environment. However, since we still need to maintain the office expense and make a living, we have some questions on the model:

1: When we treat patients with chemotherapy, we have high cost of office and staffs expenses, the administration fee on the procedures are needed to maintain the cost, how do you reimburse these kind of procedure since each chemotherapy procedures has different time, supplies and skill.etc. Procedure fee and drug margin will consist about 70% of profit margin, if these are going down so much, lots of small to medium  practices will close the door, patients will have more difficulty on choosing doctors and also big groups or big hospitals will control the price more.

2. CMS mentioned the private sectors can compete with each other even physicians or hospitals or GPO or special pharmaciesetc, if these healthcare sectors have been having conflicts of interest, how can that be able to lower the cost? Also, to create one more layer of middleman in the delivery of healthcare may actually increase cost?

3. If CMS implement this kind of medication method, will all insurance companies follow through? Otherwise, it will be more cost to the providers since they need to provide more staffs to accommodate different payment systems. The high cost of healthcare is not only because of medication but also the complication on the whole supplies chain on how healthcare provided to patients.  Government should maintain all centralize payment clearing house, EMR, authorization system, health data information exchange to reduce cost. Healthcare providers are spending so much money, time and energy to follow the guidelines, dig into different medical records, asking for referral and authorization and accommodate on different EMR system.etc.

4. Since FDA keep approving the drugs coming into market and also the NCCN or other guidelines has put these expensive drugs at early stage, we treat patients according to the guidelines, so it is not physician offices fault to use the high price medication.
title: Winni Wong, TX

title: TN

commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

commentText:
December 27, 2018

Via Federal eRulemaking Portal: http://www.regulations.gov

Seema Verma
Administrator
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services 
Department of Health and Human Services
P.O. Box 8013
Baltimore, MD 21244-8013

Re: 	CMS-5528-ANPRM
	Comments on CMS Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking International Pricing Index Model for Medicare Part B Drugs 

Dear Administrator Verma:

Sioux Center Health appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking ("Advanced Notice") regarding the International Pricing Index (IPI) Model for Medicare Part B Drugs.  Sioux Center Health is a critical access hospital (CAH) that participates in the 340B program by virtue of providing safety net services to individuals located in rural and remote locations in the United States. CAHs face significant financial challenges and often struggle to keep their doors open. In fact, 90 rural hospitals have closed since 2010.  

We applaud the Administration's efforts to address the issue of high drug prices. CMS appears to be focused on using the IPI Model to test changes in payment for drugs that are currently paid by Medicare Part B based on average sales price (ASP). CMS intends for the IPI Model to incentivize providers to seek out lower costs for drugs and reduce inappropriate utilization by changing the add-on payment for drugs paid based on ASP. However, CMS has solicited feedback on whether to include CAHs in the IPI Model. Medicare recognizes that CAHs are unique and pays CAHs based on costs, not ASP. As providers that are not paid based on ASP, CMS does not need to include CAHs in the model to achieve its goals. For this reason and given the unique patient populations that we treat, and the challenges rural patients could face in accessing care if our hospital were included in the model, we ask that CMS exclude CAHs from the model. 



In addition, we are concerned that including our hospital in the IPI Model could limit our patients access to Part B drugs or disrupt their treatment. For example, model vendors could restrict how hospitals order drugs by requiring hospitals to submit patient and/or prescription information prior to shipping the drugs, limiting which hospital locations are able to receive drug shipments, or limiting the amount of inventory hospitals are able to access in advance of patient treatment. Such disruptions to the distribution system could also increase white/brown bagging practices, which could lead to drug safety and efficacy issues for patients. This impact would be especially problematic for our patients who may need to travel significant distances to receive care. For example, Avera Health is a rural healthcare system that spans over a four state area.  We try to help local patients receive services and infusions closer to home at their rural hospitals when working with specialty physicians within the Avera Health system to improve patient care and minimize patient travel time and costs.   


Participating in the IPI Model would also create operational burdens that could affect our ability to treat patients. Model participants would need to track model drugs given to Part B patients, which would require the creation of a manual process or investment in software to track model drugs. These operational burdens would be especially challenging for 340B hospitals, which already operate complex management systems to manage 340B and non-340B drug inventories. Imposing additional inventory tracking requirements on 340B hospitals would strain our scarce resources and further limit our ability to treat rural patients. 

We appreciate the opportunity to provide comments on this Advanced Notice. For the reasons outlined above, we respectfully urge CMS to exclude CAHs from the IPI Model.

Sincerely,

Sioux Center Health

title: SD

commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

commentText: Attached is a comment letter from the Campaign for Sustainable Rx Pricing (CSRxP) on CMS-5528-ANPRM.
title: DC

commentText:
December 27, 2018

Via Federal eRulemaking Portal: http://www.regulations.gov

Seema Verma
Administrator
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services 
Department of Health and Human Services
P.O. Box 8013
Baltimore, MD 21244-8013

Re: 	CMS-5528-ANPRM
	Comments on CMS Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking International Pricing Index Model for Medicare Part B Drugs 

Dear Administrator Verma:

Freeman Regional Health Services appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking ("Advanced Notice") regarding the International Pricing Index (IPI) Model for Medicare Part B Drugs.  Freeman Regional Health Services is a critical access hospital (CAH) that participates in the 340B program by virtue of providing safety net services to individuals located in rural and remote locations in the United States. CAHs face significant financial challenges and often struggle to keep their doors open. In fact, 90 rural hospitals have closed since 2010.  

We applaud the Administration's efforts to address the issue of high drug prices. CMS appears to be focused on using the IPI Model to test changes in payment for drugs that are currently paid by Medicare Part B based on average sales price (ASP). CMS intends for the IPI Model to incentivize providers to seek out lower costs for drugs and reduce inappropriate utilization by changing the add-on payment for drugs paid based on ASP. However, CMS has solicited feedback on whether to include CAHs in the IPI Model. Medicare recognizes that CAHs are unique and pays CAHs based on costs, not ASP. As providers that are not paid based on ASP, CMS does not need to include CAHs in the model to achieve its goals. For this reason and given the unique patient populations that we treat, and the challenges rural patients could face in accessing care if our hospital were included in the model, we ask that CMS exclude CAHs from the model. 



In addition, we are concerned that including our hospital in the IPI Model could limit our patients access to Part B drugs or disrupt their treatment. For example, model vendors could restrict how hospitals order drugs by requiring hospitals to submit patient and/or prescription information prior to shipping the drugs, limiting which hospital locations are able to receive drug shipments, or limiting the amount of inventory hospitals are able to access in advance of patient treatment. Such disruptions to the distribution system could also increase white/brown bagging practices, which could lead to drug safety and efficacy issues for patients. This impact would be especially problematic for our patients who may need to travel significant distances to receive care. For example, Avera Health is a rural healthcare system that spans over a four state area.  We try to help local patients receive services and infusions closer to home at their rural hospitals when working with specialty physicians within the Avera Health system to improve patient care and minimize patient travel time and costs.   

Participating in the IPI Model would also create operational burdens that could affect our ability to treat patients. Model participants would need to track model drugs given to Part B patients, which would require the creation of a manual process or investment in software to track model drugs. These operational burdens would be especially challenging for 340B hospitals, which already operate complex management systems to manage 340B and non-340B drug inventories. Imposing additional inventory tracking requirements on 340B hospitals would strain our scarce resources and further limit our ability to treat rural patients. 

We appreciate the opportunity to provide comments on this Advanced Notice. For the reasons outlined above, we respectfully urge CMS to exclude CAHs from the IPI Model.

Sincerely,

Freeman Regional Health Services

commentText:
We, organizations representing patients, physicians, hospitals, payers, and healthcare innovators appreciate this opportunity to comment on the Departments Advanced Notice of Proposed Rule Making (ANPRM) regarding the International Price Index Model (IPI) for drugs dispensed under the Medicare Part B program.

We have a shared belief that Medicare should be more quality-driven, cost-efficient, and patient-focused, and we believe the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation (CMMI) is a key asset in achieving this goal.  We believe, though, that CMMI demonstrations should be limited in scope as they test new payment and delivery concepts.  We further believe that there must be public transparency and collaboration with healthcare stakeholders as well as vigilant monitoring and quality evaluation to protect Medicare beneficiaries.  We are writing today to urge you not to move forward with the proposed IPI model.


See attached file for full comments.

Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

commentText: As a Family Physician, I am well aware of the high prices of certain drugs, especially new ones.  When patients are helped to price-shop, they can often save large amounts.  We need more policies that encourage competition, not "price controls" to further reduce prices.   A big help would be to require all new drugs to be compared to current standard therapy.   Another would be for the FDA to adopt reciprocity in the approval of new drugs with their counterparts in other advanced countries.  To arbitrarily control prices will only curtail supply.  We are already painfully aware of short supply of many essential generic pharmaceuticals because prices have fallen so low.   Do not add to this problem.

commentText:
Dear Administrator Verma, 

I work for a Home Infusion Company and play a vital role in the coordination and care for our patients in need of life saving intravenous drugs in their home. Specifically Milrinone or inotrope therapy for end stage heart failure patients. This drug is used for getting the patient with heart failure stronger prior to heart transplant/lifesaving advanced surgical options, or palliative therapy. I've seen firsthand the difference or improvement this medication makes in patients who are suffering with this disease. 

I am writing today to ask you and CMS to REVERSE the policy known as the 21st Century Cures Act and further defined in the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018. In these Act's, Medicare would reimburse for an infusion drug administration calendar day for Milrinone only if a nurse or skilled professional is physically present in the patients home. This should not a realistic expectation to have daily nursing for this population of patients to get reimbursed. Nor would our patients want daily nursing visits, our patients have said to do so would make them feel like "prisoners in their home because of their heart condition." 

Instead Home Infusion Companies like mine are able to provide this complex therapy for our patients with weekly nursing visits safely in the home, a less costly location for treatment, while promoting independence and overall health due to less time spent in a hospital. Because so much goes into providing this therapy at home, from care coordination, clinical assessments, remote monitoring, pumps, supplies, mixing or compounding the medication, shipping and all other complexities that are involved with providing this beneficial treatment for Medicare beneficiaries in their home I'm asking CMS to change the current reimbursement for Milrinone in the home. 

CMS's final rule is wholly inadequate to cover home infusion  services and would cause home infusion suppliers to discontinue providing services to Medicare beneficiaries, forcing patients to receive their infusion in much costlier settings or not to be able to receive this life saving drug at all and end up dying. There are several publications noted that CMS budget estimates on which payment is based were erroneously calculated. Because of this it will be impossible for home infusion companies like mine to stay in business providing this life saving drug, Milrinone, for our patients. 

I am strongly urging CMS to do the following:

1) Remove the requirement that a skilled professional be physically present in the patients home in order to bill for home infusion therapy services 

2) Clarify that home infusion services be reimbursed on any day on which a patients receives professional services associated with parenteral administration of a part B covered drug and biologic administered through catheters and/or needles in the home

3) Broaden the definition of professional services to include initial and ongoing assessment, plan of care development, drug preparation, care coordination and other professional services. 

Finally in closing, I am asking on behalf of the patients I serve who are beneficiaries of Medicare and have a Part B covered diagnosis that CMS REVERSE this policy and issue additional rule making or guidance to interpret "infusion drug administration calendar day" to include the diverse array of services that are required to safety furnish infusion services in the patients home. Please feel free to contact me at tfreedlander@soleohealth.com or 954-609-8699

Sincerely, 


Teri Freedlander
Territory Manager
Soleo Health Specialty Infusion Company

title: NJ

commentText:
The pilot program proposed by The Department of Health and Human Services that would set prices for certain prescription drugs in Medicare Part B based on what foreign countries pay for these drugs will harm patient choice and hurt innovation. These countries use socialized health systems, where prescription drugs are rationed or not even provided. Although our healthcare system has many issues and market-based reforms are needed, this is a step in the wrong direction.
 
Not only would this demonstration limit what prescription drugs seniors may have access to, it would disproportionately affect patients with debilitating chronic conditions like Crohn's disease, multiple sclerosis, cancer and lupus, by instituting new barriers into the program. 
 
This proposal would also hurt the development of future cures. The United States leads the world in developing new drugs, thanks to our innovative economy and research environment. This proposal fundamentally undermines this system, reducing the ability for companies to research and develop the next generation of medicine. This is an unacceptable side effect, bordering on negligence in trading our future health for a policy which will harm seniors now.
 
These policies don't work abroad and playing with them on needed medicines here will be detrimental to American seniors and our country as a whole.

commentText:
December 27, 2018

Via Federal eRulemaking Portal: http://www.regulations.gov

Seema Verma
Administrator
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services 
Department of Health and Human Services
P.O. Box 8013
Baltimore, MD 21244-8013

Re: 	CMS-5528-ANPRM
	Comments on CMS Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking International Pricing Index Model for Medicare Part B Drugs 

Dear Administrator Verma:

Avera St. Anthonys Hospital appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking ("Advanced Notice") regarding the International Pricing Index (IPI) Model for Medicare Part B Drugs.  Avera St. Anthonys Hospital is a critical access hospital (CAH) that participates in the 340B program by virtue of providing safety net services to individuals located in rural and remote locations in the United States. CAHs face significant financial challenges and often struggle to keep their doors open. In fact, 90 rural hospitals have closed since 2010.  

We applaud the Administration's efforts to address the issue of high drug prices. CMS appears to be focused on using the IPI Model to test changes in payment for drugs that are currently paid by Medicare Part B based on average sales price (ASP). CMS intends for the IPI Model to incentivize providers to seek out lower costs for drugs and reduce inappropriate utilization by changing the add-on payment for drugs paid based on ASP. However, CMS has solicited feedback on whether to include CAHs in the IPI Model. Medicare recognizes that CAHs are unique and pays CAHs based on costs, not ASP. As providers that are not paid based on ASP, CMS does not need to include CAHs in the model to achieve its goals. For this reason and given the unique patient populations that we treat, and the challenges rural patients could face in accessing care if our hospital were included in the model, we ask that CMS exclude CAHs from the model. 



In addition, we are concerned that including our hospital in the IPI Model could limit our patients access to Part B drugs or disrupt their treatment. For example, model vendors could restrict how hospitals order drugs by requiring hospitals to submit patient and/or prescription information prior to shipping the drugs, limiting which hospital locations are able to receive drug shipments, or limiting the amount of inventory hospitals are able to access in advance of patient treatment. Such disruptions to the distribution system could also increase white/brown bagging practices, which could lead to drug safety and efficacy issues for patients. This impact would be especially problematic for our patients who may need to travel significant distances to receive care. For example, Avera Health is a rural healthcare system that spans over a four state area.  We try to help local patients receive services and infusions closer to home at their rural hospitals when working with specialty physicians within the Avera Health system to improve patient care and minimize patient travel time and costs.   


Participating in the IPI Model would also create operational burdens that could affect our ability to treat patients. Model participants would need to track model drugs given to Part B patients, which would require the creation of a manual process or investment in software to track model drugs. These operational burdens would be especially challenging for 340B hospitals, which already operate complex management systems to manage 340B and non-340B drug inventories. Imposing additional inventory tracking requirements on 340B hospitals would strain our scarce resources and further limit our ability to treat rural patients. 

We appreciate the opportunity to provide comments on this Advanced Notice. For the reasons outlined above, we respectfully urge CMS to exclude CAHs from the IPI Model.

Sincerely,

Avera St. Anthonys Hospital
